definition:
The [*partition function* ]{} $p(n)$ is defined to be the number of
partitions of the integer $n$. The sequence of values
$p(0), p(1), p(2),\ldots$ is Sloane’s A000041 and begins
$1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 15, 22, 30, \ldots$. This function grows very
quickly, as we see in the following theorem due to Hardy and .

As $n \rightarrow \infty$, the ratio of $p(n)$ and
$$\frac{ e^{\pi \sqrt{ 2n/3} } } {4n \sqrt{3} }$$ approaches 1.

The generating function of $p(n)$ is called $F$: by definition

$$F(x) = \sum _{n=0} ^\infty p(n) x ^n.$$

$F$ can be written as an infinite product:

$$F(x) = \prod _{i=1} ^\infty (1-x^i) ^{-1}.$$ To see this, expand each
term in the product as a power series:

$$\label{product} \prod _{i=1} ^\infty  (1+ x^i + x^{2i} + x^{3i} + \cdots ).$$
Now expand this as a power series. Given a partition of $n$ with $a_i$
parts of size $i \geq 1$, we get a term $x^n$ in this expansion by
choosing $x^{a_1}$ from the first term in the product, $x^{2a_2}$ from
the second, $x^{3a_3}$ from the third and so on. Clearly any term $x^n$
in the expansion arises in this way from a partition of $n$.

One can prove in the same way that the generating function $F_m$ for the
number $p_m(n)$ of partitions of $n$ into at most $m$ parts (or
equivalently into parts of size at most $m$) is

$$F_m(x) = \prod _{i=1} ^m (1-x^i) ^{-1}.$$

[5]{} G. H. Hardy and E. M. Wright, [*An Introduction to the Theory of
Numbers*]{}, Oxford University Press, 2003.
